questions.text: Which of the following drugs work as an antagonist of NMDA receptors? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketamine

 

Ketamine is a well-known NMDA receptor antagonist. It binds to the NMDA receptor, blocking the action of glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter. This blockade of NMDA receptors contributes to Ketamine's unique dissociative anesthetic effects, analgesia, and other clinical applications.

 

Mnemonic

 

  • K - Kids: preferred anaesthetic agent in pediatric patients.
  • E - Emergency Reaction: CNS side effects during recovery.
  • T – Thalamocortical junction responsible for dissociative anesthesia, a primary characteristic of ketamine.
  • A - Analgesic. Known as the most potent analgesic among anesthetic agents.
  • M - Meals: Can be administered even with a full stomach, unlike many anesthetics.
  • I - ↑BP/↑IOP/↑ICP: Indicates that ketamine can increase blood pressure (BP), intraocular pressure (IOP), and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • N - NMDA Antagonist: The primary mechanism of action for ketamine, blocking NMDA receptors which is crucial in its role as an anesthetic.
  • E – Excellent Bronchodilator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine, a class of drugs that enhance the inhibitory effects of GABA. It does not interact directly with NMDA receptors.

 

Option C. Propofol: Propofol primarily acts by enhancing the activity of GABA receptors. It does not have any significant antagonist action at NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate that also works by enhancing GABAergic transmission. It lacks any direct antagonist effect on NMDA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NMDA Antagonist drugs: (Mnemonic – Kill NMDA Receptors)

 

  • K – Ketamine & S-ketamine
  • N - Nitrous Oxide
  • M - Memantine
  • D - Dextromethorphan
  • A - Amantadine
  • R - Riluzole

questions.text: All of the following are true about Kleine-Levin syndrome (KLS), EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anorexia

 

Explanation:


Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS), sometimes referred to as “Sleeping Beauty Syndrome,” is a rare sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of:

  • Hypersomnia (sleeping up to 18–20 hours a day),
  • Hyperphagia (excessive eating),
  • Hypersexuality, and
  • Behavioral disinhibition.

 

These episodes typically last days to weeks, and in between episodes, individuals return to baseline functioning. KLS most often begins in male adolescents, usually between the ages of 10 -21years. KLS is marked by hyperphagia, not reduced appetite (Anorexia). The presence of voracious eating during episodes is a defining characteristic that helps differentiate it from other conditions with excessive sleepiness.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Sleeping Beauty Syndrome: This is a well-known nickname for KLS, reflecting the extended sleep durations during episodes.
  • Option C. Hypersomnia: This is a core diagnostic feature. Patients often sleep nearly continuously for days, only waking to eat or use the bathroom.
  • Option D. Hypersexuality: Frequently observed in KLS. It includes increased libido, inappropriate sexual behavior, or disinhibition during episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kleine-Levin Syndrome is defined by episodic hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality, with complete resolution between episodes.

questions.text: Which ganglia is affected due to the involvement of the nerve located at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pterygopalatine ganglia

 

The marked area on the skull image points to a region near the pterygoid plates and the palatine bone, specifically associated with the pterygopalatine fossa. This fossa houses the pterygopalatine ganglion, which is responsible for relaying parasympathetic nerve fibers from the facial nerve to the lacrimal glands, nasal glands, and palatine glands.

 

The pterygopalatine ganglion is located within the pterygopalatine fossa, a small space beneath the apex of the orbit, posterior to the maxilla. The ganglion receives preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve, and is involved in various autonomic functions related to the glands in the region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submandibular ganglia: This ganglion is located below the mandible and is associated with the submandibular and sublingual glands. It is not related to the region marked in the image, which is closer to the pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Option B. Ciliary ganglia: The ciliary ganglion is located in the orbit and is associated with the eye, specifically controlling the ciliary muscle and the sphincter pupillae. It is not related to the marked area on the skull image.

 

Option D. Otic ganglia: The otic ganglion is associated with the parotid gland and is located just below the foramen ovale. While it plays a role in salivary secretion, it is not connected to the region indicated in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterygopalatine ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands. This ganglion is specifically affected by involvement in the region marked in the skull image.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with cough, fever, and pneumonia. A biopsy reveals the cells shown in the image. Which organism is responsible for this finding? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

 

The image provided shows cells with the characteristic "owl eye" appearance, which is a classic histopathological finding in infections caused by Cytomegalovirus (CMV). CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause severe infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, such as those on immunosuppressive therapy.

 

The "owl eye" appearance refers to the large intranuclear inclusion bodies surrounded by a clear halo, resembling an owl's eye. This appearance is due to the replication of the virus within the nucleus of the infected cell, leading to the formation of these inclusion bodies. In CMV infections, both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic basophilic inclusions can be observed, which is a key diagnostic feature.

 

CMV commonly causes pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, organ transplant recipients, or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. The virus can also cause other severe complications, including retinitis, colitis, and encephalitis.

 

Note – Ganciclovir - Preferred antiviral medication for treating CMV infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus: Poxviruses, such as the variola virus (which causes smallpox), typically produce skin lesions and are not known for causing the "owl eye" appearance in cells. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with conditions such as infectious mononucleosis and certain lymphomas, like Burkitt's lymphoma. It does not typically produce the "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Chickenpox (Varicella-Zoster Virus): Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, is characterized by vesicular skin lesions and does not produce the "owl eye" appearance in histological sections. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl eye" appearance of cells in a biopsy is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This feature is crucial for diagnosing CMV-related complications, such as CMV pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in extracellular ion concentrations will make a nerve most excitable at rest? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Increasing extracellular K+

 

Explanation:

 

Increasing extracellular K+ makes a nerve most excitable because it depolarizes the resting membrane potential. When extracellular K+ increases (hyperkalemia), the concentration gradient for K+ decreases, reducing K+ efflux from the cell. This causes the resting membrane potential to move closer to the threshold potential, making the neuron more excitable. In mild to moderate hyperkalemia, this decreased gradient leads to K+ accumulation inside cells, causing depolarization and increased excitability.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Decreasing extracellular Na+ Decreasing extracellular Na+ primarily reduces the frequency of the action potential but has minimal effect on the resting membrane potential. This occurs because Na+ permeability is relatively low at rest (0.04 compared to K+ at 1), so changes in Na+ concentration have little impact on excitability.
  • Option B. Increasing extracellular Na+ The permeability of the membrane to Na+ at rest is relatively low, so increasing extracellular Na+ has little effect on the resting membrane potential or excitability. The RMP is primarily determined by K+ gradient since K+ has much higher permeability at rest.
  • Option D. Increasing extracellular Cl- Increasing extracellular Cl- would push the membrane potential more negative (hyperpolarization) since Cl- influx has a hyperpolarizing effect. This would move the membrane potential further from threshold, making the neuron less excitable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradient, and alterations in extracellular K+ concentration have significant effects on neuronal excitability - hyperkalemia increases excitability by bringing the membrane potential closer to threshold.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD complaining of swelling in the neck region, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is the correct treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk procedure

 

The clinical presentation of a neck swelling that moves with deglutition (swallowing) and protrusion of the tongue is highly suggestive of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This congenital anomaly arises from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which can form cysts anywhere along the duct's path from the base of the tongue to the thyroid gland.

 

The definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, whether it is inflamed, ruptured, or has formed a fistula, is the Sistrunk procedure. This surgical procedure involves the removal of the cyst along with the entire thyroglossal tract and a portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be necessary if there is an infection, they do not treat the underlying cyst and would not prevent recurrence.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This approach may be used if there is an abscess formation, but it is not definitive treatment and would not prevent recurrence of the cyst or fistula.

 

Option D. Excision: Simple excision of the cyst alone is not sufficient as it does not remove the entire thyroglossal tract or part of the hyoid bone, leading to a high risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk procedure is the definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the excision of the cyst, the entire thyroglossal tract, and part of the hyoid bone to ensure complete removal and prevent recurrence.

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

 

MHC Class II molecules are specifically involved in presenting exogenous antigens, ( antigens foreign to the body eg antigens of bacteria, viruses etc)  not endogenous ( self-antigens). These exogenous antigens are typically derived from organisms outside the cell, such as bacteria or viruses that have been ingested by the cell via phagocytosis or endocytosis. MHC Class II then presents peptides from these processed antigens to CD4+ T cells, triggering an immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells: True, which is a key component of the immune response modulation.

 

Option B. The action of MHC II occurs via the endocytic pathway: True, this pathway involves the processing of phagocytosed material.

 

Option D. MHC II is present on antigen-presenting cells: True, which is essential for initiating the immune response by interacting with CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which ion primarily drives the depolarization phase of action potential in cardiac muscles? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Na+

 

Explanation:


The action potential in cardiac muscles is initiated by the rapid influx of sodium ions (Na+) during Phase 0, the phase of rapid depolarization. This sudden influx results from the opening of fast sodium channels, which causes a sharp rise in the membrane potential towards a positive value. This process is crucial for initiating the sequence of electrical events that lead to muscle contraction. Sodium's role is pivotal in setting the fast response of cardiac myocytes, which differentiates cardiac muscle action potential from those in other types of muscle cells.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. K+: While potassium ions (K+) play significant roles in the initial repolarization (Phase 1) and final repolarization (Phase 3) by exiting the cell, they do not initiate the action potential.
  • Option c. Ca+2: Calcium ions contribute mainly to the Plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential by entering the cell through slow voltage-gated channels, sustaining the depolarization longer than in other muscle cells, but they are not the primary trigger.
  • Option d. Cl: Chloride ions have minimal direct involvement in the generation or progression of cardiac action potentials.

 

Educational objective:


The initiation of the action potential in cardiac muscle cells is primarily driven by the influx of Na+ ions during the rapid depolarization phase, critical for the subsequent phases of the cardiac cycle.

choices.text: It is less than anatomical dead space
It can be measured by spirometry
It is because of inadequate perfusion
It is because of inadequate ventilation

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about physiological dead space? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is because of inadequate perfusion

 

Physiological dead space refers to the total volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange. It is composed of two components: anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space.

 

Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of air in the conducting airways (from the nose to the terminal bronchioles) that doesn't participate in gas exchange due to the structural anatomy of the respiratory system. The alveolar dead space refers to the volume of air that reaches the alveoli but doesn't participate in gas exchange due to inadequate perfusion of those alveoli.

 

When there is inadequate perfusion (blood flow) to normally ventilated alveoli, a ventilation-perfusion mismatch occurs. This is known as "wasted ventilation" - air reaches the alveoli but since there is insufficient blood flow, the gases cannot be exchanged effectively. This contributes to the physiological dead space.

 

"If there is inadequate perfusion, the alveoli are fine but the problem is in the capillaries. If there is obstruction in the capillaries, fewer molecules of hemoglobin are available to transport oxygen. The remaining oxygen molecules will stay in the alveoli, becoming unexchanged air. This wasted ventilation due to inadequate perfusion adds to physiological dead space."

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is less than anatomical dead space: This is incorrect because physiological dead space equals anatomical dead space in healthy individuals (where alveolar dead space is zero) or exceeds it in pathological conditions (where alveolar dead space is greater than zero). It cannot be less than anatomical dead space because anatomical dead space is determined by the fixed structure of the conducting airways.

 

Option B. It can be measured by spirometry: This is incorrect because spirometry only measures lung volumes and flow rates; it cannot differentiate between exchanged and unexchanged air. Physiological dead space is measured using Bohr's equation, which requires measuring partial pressures of CO2 in exhaled air and arterial blood.

 

Option D. It is because of inadequate ventilation: This is incorrect because inadequate ventilation does not increase dead space. When ventilation is reduced but perfusion is normal, whatever air does reach the alveoli will be completely exchanged due to the preserved perfusion. Inadequate ventilation creates a different type of ventilation-perfusion mismatch called "wasted perfusion" rather than increasing dead space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space, with alveolar dead space occurring primarily due to inadequate perfusion of ventilated alveoli, resulting in wasted ventilation.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

 

Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. In this case, the patient presents with massive splenomegaly, fever, anemia, and other features suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), which is endemic in regions like Bihar, India. The vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania is the Phlebotomus species, commonly known as sandflies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rat fly: Rat flies are not vectors for Leishmania. They are typically associated with the spread of different diseases, like murine typhus, but not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Chrysops fly: Chrysops flies are known as deer flies and are vectors for diseases like Loiasis but are not involved in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Option D. Black fly: Black flies are vectors for Onchocerciasis (river blindness) and have no role in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common habit-forming drug is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heroin

 

Heroin is an opioid and is the most commonly abused opioid. Heroin has the highest dependence potential among all drugs listed. It is highly addictive, and users can develop a strong physical dependence, leading to withdrawal symptoms if the drug is not taken.

 

Most commonly abused drugs: This can vary from one country to another. Generally, alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, opioids are most commonly abused drugs:

 

  • Alcohol is the most common Used/Abused Substance in the World
  • Tobacco is the most common Used/Abused Substance in India
  • Cannabis is the most common “illegally” used drug in India as well as world, though its dependence potential is relatively lower.
  • Heroin is the most commonly abused opioid, and is the drug with highest dependence potential amongst all the drugs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming.

 

Option C. LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen. It can be abused, but it does not have the same level of physical dependence potential.

 

Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP): PCP is a dissociative drug with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming drug.

 

Educational Objective

 

Common habit-forming drugs:

 

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstasy
  • Cocaine

 

Heroin is the most common drug which is habit forming or in other words can cause physical dependence in which a patient gets withdrawal if he does not take the drug.

questions.text: Match the mode of inheritance with the disorder in the appropriate column: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

1. Autosomal Dominant -  D. Myotonia dystrophica

  • Autosomal dominant disorders are typically inherited from one affected parent. Myotonia dystrophica, characterized by muscle stiffness and other systemic symptoms, exhibits this pattern of inheritance.

 

2. X-Linked Recessive – A. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy

  • X-linked recessive disorders mainly affect males and are passed on by carrier mothers. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy, which leads to muscle degeneration and weakness, is a classic example.

 

3. Autosomal Recessive – C. Cystic fibrosis

  • Autosomal recessive disorders require both parents to pass on a faulty gene. Cystic fibrosis, which causes severe damage to the respiratory and digestive systems, is inherited this way.

 

4. Mitochondrial – B. Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (Leber's disease)

  • Mitochondrial diseases are inherited through mutations in mitochondrial DNA, typically passed from mother to all offspring. Leber's disease leads to sudden vision loss primarily in young adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Each genetic disorder has a specific pattern of inheritance that affects its transmission and manifestation in individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to sebaceous glands? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glands of Moll

 

  • Glands of Moll are modified apocrine glands, not sebaceous glands. 
  • They are located in the eyelids, specifically at the lid margin. 
  • The key distinction is their secretion method - apocrine glands secrete by a decapitation process where the apex of the cell is pinched off during secretion, unlike sebaceous glands which use holocrine secretion (whole cell disintegration).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zeis Glands:

 

  • These are indeed sebaceous glands associated with the eyelids. 
  • They are connected to the follicles of eyelashes and produce sebum that lubricates the eyelashes.

 

Option B. Meibomian Glands:

 

  • These are Ectopic sebaceous glands embedded in the tarsal plates of eyelids. 
  • They secrete meibum, an oily substance that forms the outer layer of the tear film and prevents evaporation.

 

Option D. Fordyce Spots:

 

  • These are ectopic sebaceous glands (not associated with hair follicles) that appear as small yellowish papules on the upper lip, buccal mucosa, and other areas.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glands of Moll are modified apocrine glands in the eyelids with decapitation-type secretion, making them distinct from sebaceous glands, which use holocrine secretion and are represented by Zeis glands, Meibomian glands, and Fordyce spots.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellow compound that occurs in the normal catabolic pathway that breaks down heme in red blood cells. There are two types of hyperbilirubinemia based on the type of bilirubin that is elevated: conjugated (direct) and unconjugated (indirect).

 

  • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs when there is an excess of bilirubin that has not been processed by the liver. This is known as indirect bilirubin. In Gilbert syndrome, there is a reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for converting unconjugated bilirubin into its conjugated form. As a result, patients with Gilbert syndrome have elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin, especially during periods of fasting, illness, or stress.

 

Note - Crigler Najjar Syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of bilirubin conjugation characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that can result in bilirubin-induced neurologic dysfunction (BIND).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin Johnson Syndrome: This syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is characterized by defective hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin due to a mutation affecting the transport protein MRP2.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: This leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare, benign condition where there is a mild defect in bilirubin storage and transport.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This is a condition in which the bile ducts inside or outside the liver do not have normal openings. This leads to a buildup of conjugated bilirubin and results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, resulting from reduced enzyme activity that impairs the conversion of unconjugated bilirubin to its conjugated form

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:


Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Phenytoin: Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.

 

Educational Objective:


Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.

questions.text: A PLHIV with low CD4 count admitted with pneumonia. GMS stain of BAL shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis

 

The image provided shows a GMS stain of BAL (Bronchoalveolar lavage) fluid, which is a common diagnostic method used to identify pathogens in patients with pneumonia. The patient is HIV-positive with a low CD4 count, indicating immunocompromise. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in such patients, often referred to as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). The hallmark appearance of Pneumocystis in a GMS stain is the black, crushed ping-pong ball-like cysts against a green background, which is visible in the image.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus: Cryptococcus usually appears as encapsulated yeast cells, often seen in India ink preparations or mucicarmine stains. It does not show the crushed ping-pong ball appearance seen in the image.

 

Option B. Mucor: Mucor species are identified by their broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typically visible on H&E or PAS stains, not GMS. The morphology seen in the image does not match Mucor.

 

Option D. Candida: Candida typically appears as budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which do not resemble the crushed ping-pong ball appearance shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is a common cause of pneumonia in HIV patients with low CD4 counts and is identified by its characteristic crushed ping-pong ball appearance in GMS-stained samples.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contaminated

 

  • In surgical practice, wounds are categorized based on their potential contamination during the procedure, which plays a crucial role in determining the risk of infection and guiding the prophylactic antibiotic therapy. Here’s an explanation of each category in the context of an open cardiac massage:

 

This category includes open, fresh, accidental wounds and operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Contaminated wounds also include incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered. Open cardiac massage often involves emergency entry into the chest, which may not always comply with optimal sterile conditions, especially in traumatic or urgent contexts, thus falling into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clean: These are wounds where no inflammation is encountered, and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Clean wounds are primarily closed and do not involve placement of a drain. The risk of infection is typically the lowest in clean wounds.

 

Option C. Dirty: These wounds involve the presence of pus or perforated viscera. This kind of wound shows evidence of a bacterial infection or major contamination prior to surgery. Dirty wounds are at high risk of developing postoperative infections.

 

Option D. Clean Contaminated: These wounds involve operations on the alimentary, respiratory, genital, or urinary tracts under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Typically, these procedures involve some minor breaks in sterile technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

 

The 5th disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by Parvovirus B19. It is a common childhood viral infection characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum contagiosum: This is not correct. Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option C. HFMD (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease): HFMD is caused by enteroviruses, primarily Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is not caused by Parvovirus B19. It is an inflammatory condition of blood vessels, and its etiology is not related to the virus responsible for the 5th disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for shoulder abduction between 15° and 90°? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) Deltoid

 

Explanation:

 

The deltoid muscle is primarily responsible for abduction of the shoulder joint from 15° to 90°. Specifically, the middle fibers of the deltoid are powerful abductors of the arm at the shoulder joint. The deltoid is a triangular muscle that covers the shoulder joint and gives the shoulder its rounded contour. It is innervated by the axillary nerve (C5, C6). The multipennate arrangement of its acromial fibers allows for strong abduction force, making it the main muscle for this movement range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Supraspinatus - While controversial, the supraspinatus is traditionally thought to initiate abduction (0°-15°) rather than being the primary muscle for 15°-90° abduction. It works synergistically with the deltoid throughout the range of motion.

 

Option b) Trapezius - The trapezius does not directly abduct the shoulder joint. Its role in shoulder abduction becomes important only beyond 90° when it rotates the scapula to allow continued overhead movement.

 

Option d) Serratus Anterior - This muscle is responsible for protraction of the scapula and works with the trapezius for scapular rotation during overhead abduction (90°-180°), but is not the primary muscle for 15°-90° glenohumeral abduction.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The deltoid muscle is the principal abductor of the shoulder joint from 15° to 90°, while complete overhead abduction (beyond 90°) requires coordinated action between the deltoid, trapezius, and serratus anterior. According to latest edition of Gray’s Anatomy (0°-15°) is controversial. New updates are saying that (0°- 90°) movement is done by deltoid & supraspinatous both muscles.

questions.text: The green-shaded region in the coronal section of the brain corresponds to which type of fibers? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Projection

 

The internal capsule, a type of projection fibre, is the marked structure.

 

Projection fibres -

 

  • Connect the cerebral cortex to other brain areas and the spinal cord.
  • These fibers run vertically, either ascending to the cortex (afferent fibers bringing in sensory information) or descending from the cortex (efferent fibers sending out motor commands).
  • The corona radiata and the internal capsule are examples of areas containing many projection fibers.
  • They facilitate communication between the cortex and other parts of the CNS like the brainstem, thalamus, and spinal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Association:

 

  • Also known as "U-fibers" or "short arcuate fibers" which connect neighboring gyrus.
  • They allow for communication between adjacent or nearby cortical regions.
  • Primarily found in the gray matter just below the cortical surface.
  • Their presence helps in localized processing and integration of information within a single cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Long Association:

 

  • Connect more distant areas within the same hemisphere.
  • Examples include the superior longitudinal fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the posterior temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, and the uncinate fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the anterior temporal lobe.
  • These fibers are crucial for integrating information across distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere.

 

Option D. Commissural:

 

  • Connect corresponding regions of the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing them to communicate with each other.
  • The most prominent example is the corpus callosum, which is the largest white matter structure in the brain and provides a broad band of neural connections between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. Other examples include the anterior commissure and the posterior commissure.
  • These fibers are essential for the two hemispheres to share information and coordinate activity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal canula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  30%

 

Explanation:

 

The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered by nasal cannula increases by approximately 4% for every 1 liter per minute of oxygen flow. Thus:

 

  • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%.
  • 2 L/min would be about 28%.
  • 3 L/min would be about 32%.

 

Given the options provided, the closest and most commonly accepted approximation for the FiO2 being delivered at a flow rate of 3 L/min through a nasal cannula would be around 30%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 1 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option C. 40%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 5 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option D. 45%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 6 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FiO2 delivered by a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min is approximately 30%.

questions.text: How many stages are described in Elisabeth Kübler-Ross model of 'coping with dying'? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Five

 

Explanation:

 

The Elisabeth Kübler-Ross model outlines five stages of grief. These stages were based on her work with terminally ill patients, though they have since been applied more broadly to anyone experiencing loss.

 

The five stages are:

 

 

These stages are not necessarily linear, and individuals may cycle through them in various orders or revisit stages over time.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Three: Some alternative models of grief suggest three phases (e.g., acute grief, integrated grief, and recovery), but this is not part of Kübler-Ross’s framework.
  • Option B. Four: While simplified adaptations might omit or combine stages, the original Kübler-Ross model contains five clearly defined stages.
  • Option D. Six: Some later interpretations have proposed a sixth stage (like "finding meaning", as suggested by David Kessler), but the classic Kübler-Ross model includes only five.

 

Educational Objective:


The Kübler-Ross model remains a foundational framework in understanding grief and loss, consisting of five stages denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance though experiences of grief are highly individual and not always stage-based.

choices.text: Rewarming with immersion in warm water
Rewarming with encouragement to walk on warm surfaces

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for frostbite on the lower extremities? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Rewarming with immersion in warm water

 

Explanation:

 

The initial treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming in a bath at 42°C. This method provides controlled rewarming at a specific temperature to prevent further tissue damage. Rapid rewarming is essential, but it must be done properly in a warm water bath to ensure even heat distribution and temperature control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rewarming with friction and/or massage - This is actively dangerous for frostbite. Frostbite causes delayed microvascular damage similar to cardiac reperfusion injury. Friction or massage would worsen this damage by potentially breaking fragile tissues that are already compromised.

 

Option B. Rewarming with blankets - This method is too slow and uncontrolled. Frostbite requires rapid rewarming at a specific temperature (42°C), which blankets cannot provide consistently.

 

Option D. Rewarming with encouragement of walking on warm surfaces - This would apply pressure to already damaged tissue. The level of damage is difficult to assess, and management is conservative until there is absolute demarcation of the level of injury. Walking would risk further injury before proper assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frostbite requires controlled, rapid rewarming in a water bath at a specific temperature (42°C) without applying pressure or friction to the damaged tissues, followed by conservative management until tissue demarcation is clear.

questions.text: Which anatomical structure is marked in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right hepatic artery

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Calot's triangle anatomy where:

 

  • Right hepatic artery is a branch of common hepatic artery
  • It gives off the cystic artery which supplies the gallbladder
  • The artery marked in the image is entering the liver, making it the right hepatic artery
  • Mistaking the right hepatic artery for the cystic artery during surgery can lead to catastrophic haemorrhage or liver ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic artery: Incorrect as cystic artery is a branch of right hepatic artery that supplies the gallbladder, not the vessel marked which is entering liver

 

Option B. Cystic duct: Incorrect as cystic duct drains gallbladder and joins common hepatic duct to form common bile duct

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: Incorrect as hepatic ducts are biliary drainage channels, not arteries

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right hepatic artery is a key structure in hepatobiliary surgery, running within Calot’s Triangle and supplying the right lobe of the liver. Identifying it correctly during cholecystectomy is crucial to avoid vascular injury.

choices.text: Primary hyperparathyroidism
Vitamin D toxicity
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is (INICET Nov 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignancy

 

Explanation:  

 

In hospitalized patients, the most common cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Malignancy-associated hypercalcemia often results from the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by cancer cells, which mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels. This is frequently seen in cancers such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism: This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients but not in hospitalized patients. It is characterized by elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to parathyroid gland hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma.

 

Option C. Vitamin D toxicity: Hypercalcemia can occur due to excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium. However, it is not the most common cause in hospitalized patients.

 

Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: This is a rare genetic condition characterized by benign hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion. It mimics primary hyperparathyroidism but is less common and typically not seen as the most frequent cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, often due to the secretion of PTHrP by cancer cells.
